awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CEDAR: Characterization of Ionospheric-Thermospheric Long-lasting SED (Storm Enhanced Density) Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration: The goal of the research is to understand the initiation and development of a phenomenon called mid-latitude long-lasting storm enhanced density (LLSED). LLSEDs are regions of enhanced electron density at low latitudes that emanate from midlatitude SED plumes. The term "plume" refers to structures in the Earth's magnetosphere and ionosphere that couple these two systems and redistribute plasma among them. LLSEDs last over 6 hours, outliving the SED plumes that spawn them, and can potentially adversely impact communication and navigation systems. However, there remains no consensus on their causes. The work skillfully fuses ground- and space-based data with numerical modeling tools to examine ionospheric disturbances that are of some concern for the aviation and telecommunication industries. The grant will support an early career minority scientist, and contribute to Catholic U's REU program.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Many aspects of ionospheric storms are still not well understood. In particular, the characteristics and driving mechanisms of long-lasting Storm Enhanced Density (LLSED) events are largely still a subject of intense debate. The overarching goal of the proposed research is to comprehensively examine the characteristics and physical processes that lead to the initiation and development of mid-latitude LLSED. 

This is a 3-year data analysis and numerical modeling effort addressing several intriguing questions concerning the characteristics and physical processes associated with mid-latitude LLSED. To successfully address the goals of this proposal requires the integration of several different resources. The data sets to be used address the need to positively identify physical processes that contribute to the LLSED formation, specifically composition, electric fields and winds. Complementing these data sets are various models that provide a framework for analysis and understanding of the LLSED formation and evolution.

From the period 2000 to 2018, we have identified and confirmed 56 LLSED events in the American sector.  We have focused on the American region because: (i) SEDs are more commonly observed in the American sector (which is thought to be related to the orientation of the geomagnetic field); (ii) it is much easier to access TEC data from the American sector than other sectors around the globe.  We found that out of the 665 geomagnetic storms between the years 2000 to 2018, only8% of the storms are associated with LLSED development. Furthermore, the statistical study also showsthat LLSED events have a strong solar cycle, local time, and longitude dependence. The statistical analysis reveals that majority (> 40%) of the LLSED events are associated with minor to moderate geomagnetic storm conditions, i.e., Dst > -100 nT.

For these 56 events, ASTRA ran high latitude assimilations using the AMIE algorithm to generate high latitude convection patterns in order to investigate the relationship between enhanced electron densities and convection electric fields.  These convection patterns were used to drive global first-principles ionosphere-thermosphere models (TIEGCM or TIMEGCM) for 52 out of 56 events, to investigate whether the models recreated the observed SED features. ASTRA also ran an assimilative ionospheric electron density model (IDA4D) for one event to study the ionospheric structure in more detail than provided by the first-principles models alone.   To validate the models and to provide insight into the mechanisms at work during LLSED events, ASTRA collected measurements of thermospheric neutral winds from the Millstone Hill Fabry-Perot interferometer (FPI) for various events. ASTRA also collected data on the thermospheric composition during these events as provided by the TIMED-GUVI and DMSP-SSUSI UV instruments for various events.  We find that a combination of driving process are likely active at different stages of geomagnetic storms and substorms, including enhanced high latitude convection and particle injection, prompt penetration electric fields, disturbance dynamo effects, neutral winds and composition.

The project has resulted in two published papers (with three others in preparation), and ten conference presentations.

Broader Impacts

The project has contributed to NSF STEM goals through mentoring and collaborations.

An experienced researcher and other staff at ASTRA have mentored a junior scientist in his research development, including encouraging him to attend multiple scientific conferences, and training him in the skills of a research career such as how to write successful proposals (he has won several during the life of this project).  In turn the junior scientist has mentored undergraduate students from University of Maryland. They were retained to work on the project, and they each were lead authors on scientific presentations at important scientific conferences.  We have also worked with a two-year/community college Minority Serving Institution (MSI) to develop innovations in curriculum and experiential learning opportunities. Various international collaborations have been seeded by the project, including a STEM initiative in Zambia, and ASTRA staff helped an ionospheric scientist in Nigeria put together a Research Plan to develop a robust ionospheric research program in Nigeria.
